articles.headline: Trump’s Industry Criticisms Shift Detroit Auto Show’s Focus
articles.snippet: Ford and Fiat Chrysler announced at the show that they would create jobs in the United States as the industry grappled with what direction to take.
articles.abstract: Ford and Fiat Chrysler announced at the show that they would create jobs in the United States as the industry grappled with what direction to take.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — President-elect Donald J. Trump is not attending the country’s premier auto show here. But his vow to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico has changed the focus of the show from what new vehicles are on display to where they are made.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Jared Kushner Named Senior White House Adviser to Donald Trump
articles.snippet: The move cements Mr. Kushner’s role as a powerful and at times decisive influence on Mr. Trump, his father-in-law.
articles.abstract: The move cements Mr. Kushner’s role as a powerful and at times decisive influence on Mr. Trump, his father-in-law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jared Kushner will become a senior White House adviser to his father-in-law, Donald J. Trump, cementing the New York real estate executive’s role as a powerful and at times decisive influence on the president-elect.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Women’s March on Washington Opens Contentious Dialogues About Race
articles.snippet: Conversations surrounding the march on Jan. 21, the day after Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, are alienating some women even as organizers stress unity and inclusion.
articles.abstract: Conversations surrounding the march on Jan. 21, the day after Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, are alienating some women even as organizers stress unity and inclusion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many thousands of women are expected to converge on the nation’s capital for the Women’s March on Washington the day after Donald J. Trump’s inauguration. Jennifer Willis no longer plans to be one of them.

articles.headline: Specialty Pharmacies Say Benefit Managers Are Squeezing Them Out
articles.snippet: The pharmacies, which often sell high-cost drugs for rare diseases to relatively few patients, complain of being cut from benefit managers’ networks.
articles.abstract: The pharmacies, which often sell high-cost drugs for rare diseases to relatively few patients, complain of being cut from benefit managers’ networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: From its storefront in Union City, N.J., Prime Aid Pharmacy caters to patients with a wide range of ailments, from rheumatoid arthritis to hepatitis C. The business prides itself on getting patients their necessary drugs, employs a staff that speaks 10 languages and delivers medications by car in New York and New Jersey.

articles.headline: Israel Buries 4 Soldiers, but the Mourning Is Marred by Discord
articles.snippet: As funerals were held for victims of a truck attack Sunday in Jerusalem, Israelis remained divided over a soldier’s conviction for killing a wounded and incapacitated Palestinian terrorist.
articles.abstract: As funerals were held for victims of a truck attack Sunday in Jerusalem, Israelis remained divided over a soldier’s conviction for killing a wounded and incapacitated Palestinian terrorist.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — One loved horse riding; another was the oldest of four sisters; a third had fought to enlist in the army despite medical problems that allowed him to defer the draft. The fourth was the 300th  graduate of her Haifa high school to have died while serving as a soldier.

articles.headline: Betsy DeVos, Trump’s Education Pick, Plays Hardball With Her Wealth
articles.snippet: The stalwart of Michigan politics and backer of school vouchers has not been shy about advancing her goals by funding campaigns against her foes.
articles.abstract: The stalwart of Michigan politics and backer of school vouchers has not been shy about advancing her goals by funding campaigns against her foes.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Tom Casperson, a Republican state senator from Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, began running for Congress in 2016, he assumed the family of Betsy DeVos, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s nominee to be education secretary, would not oppose him.

articles.headline: Critics Say Trump Appointees Can Dodge a Huge Tax Bill. That’s Not the Case.
articles.snippet: Analysts and politicians have denounced a law that they say offers a tax shelter for rich government appointees. But that’s not how the rule works.
articles.abstract: Analysts and politicians have denounced a law that they say offers a tax shelter for rich government appointees. But that’s not how the rule works.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Not only is Donald Trump giving a gang of billionaires control of our government, he’s offering them a special tax break just for signing up.”

articles.headline: Muted Response From Health Lobby as Affordable Care Act Faces Repeal
articles.snippet: Fearing they will anger the new administration, some lobbyists have accepted that major provisions are likely to be repealed and have set their sights instead on shaping a replacement.
articles.abstract: Fearing they will anger the new administration, some lobbyists have accepted that major provisions are likely to be repealed and have set their sights instead on shaping a replacement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The speed of Republican efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act has stunned health industry lobbyists, leaving representatives of insurance companies, hospitals, doctors and pharmaceutical makers in disarray and struggling for a response to a legislative quick strike that would upend much of the American health care system.

articles.headline: Volkswagen Executive’s Trip to U.S. Allowed F.B.I. to Pounce
articles.snippet: Federal agents arrested Oliver Schmidt, a top Volkswagen official now charged in the emissions scandal, as he prepared to depart Miami for Germany on Saturday night.
articles.abstract: Federal agents arrested Oliver Schmidt, a top Volkswagen official now charged in the emissions scandal, as he prepared to depart Miami for Germany on Saturday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: When F.B.I. agents learned that a prime suspect in the Volkswagen emissions scandal was traveling to the United States, investigators knew they were on the cusp of a rare feat: the arrest of an overseas corporate executive accused of wrongdoing.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Adam Goldman and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Publishers Encounter Political Storms in Turn to Right
articles.snippet: The largely left-leaning publishing world is courting young conservatives and tailoring its plans to reflect volatile new political realities.
articles.abstract: The largely left-leaning publishing world is courting young conservatives and tailoring its plans to reflect volatile new political realities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Milo Yiannopoulos — the infamous internet troll, Donald J. Trump supporter and editor at Breitbart News — has compared Islam to cancer, mocked transgender people and suggested that women who are harassed online should stay off the web. Last July, he was permanently barred from Twitter for violating the platform’s rules against hate speech and harassment.

articles.headline: Obama’s Farewell Address: ‘Yes, We Did’
articles.snippet: The president’s final speech to the nation was marked by nostalgia and hope, though he warned that racial, political and economic challenges still lie ahead.
articles.abstract: The president’s final speech to the nation was marked by nostalgia and hope, though he warned that racial, political and economic challenges still lie ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — President Obama delivered a nostalgic and hopeful farewell address to the nation on Tuesday evening, but warned both the divided country he led for eight years and his successor not to shrink from the challenges of economic inequality, racial strife, political isolation and voter apathy that still threaten its ideal of democracy.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Prisons Run by C.E.O.s? Privatization Under Trump Could Carry a Heavy Price
articles.snippet: Privatization is being portrayed as a surefire way to deliver better services for less public money, but a body of economics suggests this belief is false.
articles.abstract: Privatization is being portrayed as a surefire way to deliver better services for less public money, but a body of economics suggests this belief is false.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, the Justice Department decided to start winding down its use of private prisons.
